title: Torque and work - torques on two disks

content.question: Disks <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> and <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> are initially at rest. Strings with negligible mass are wrapped around the edge of each disk and the strings are pulled with equal forces of magnitude <math alttext="F" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>F</mi></math>, as shown. The disks are free to rotate about their centers with negligible friction. Disk <math alttext="A" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>A</mtext></math> has radius <math alttext="r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and rotational inertia <math alttext="I sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Disk <math alttext="B" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mtext>B</mtext></math> has radius <math alttext="2 r sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>2</mn><msub><mi>r</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math> and rotational inertia <math alttext="4 I sub 0" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mn>4</mn><msub><mi>I</mi><mn>0</mn></msub></math>. Which expression correctly relates the change in rotational kinetic energy, <math alttext="delta K" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mstyle displaystyle="true"><mtext>Δ</mtext><mi>K</mi></mstyle></math>, of the two disks after each string has been pulled a linear distance <math alttext="x" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>x</mi></math>?
